title.children: Defence charged over 2021 truck rollover that killed two soldiers

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has ended lower after the economy slowed down from June last year because of higher interest rates and weakening demand. The ASX 200 index dropped 0.8 per cent with most sectors ending down aside from energy stocks, which rose on higher prices. Education firms, consumer companies, technology, banks, and miners were among the losers today. The Australian dollar traded near a ten month low of below 64 US cents on fears about China's weakening economy. It came off its overnight low of 63.58 US cents to 63.95 US cents in the late afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Slowing growth weighs on ASX and Australian dollar

children.content: The Australian share market has ended lower after the economy slowed down from June last year because of higher interest rates and weakening demand.
The ASX 200 index dropped 0.8 per cent with most sectors ending down aside from energy stocks, which rose on higher prices.
Education firms, consumer companies, technology, banks, and miners were among the losers today.
The Australian dollar traded near a ten month low of below 64 US cents on fears about China's weakening economy.
It came off its overnight low of 63.58 US cents to 63.95 US cents in the late afternoon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we've been focusing on today, the economy is being weighed down by higher interest rates after 12 increases since May last year. Consumer spending was anaemic over the June quarter, and Australia saw the largest fall in the terms of trade, the difference between export and import prices, since June 2009. The ABS says a warmer northern hemisphere winter reduced demand for coal and liquefied natural gas. Also iron ore prices fell because of weaker demand from China's construction and manufacturing industries. While prices fell, exports rose, driven by more international students coming here for education and increased tourism. HSBC chief economist Paul Bloxham says the Reserve Bank's interest rate rises are working to cool the economy. "Today's GDP figures are likely to have been welcomed by the RBA   and, in particular, by Governor Lowe, whose seven-year term is about to end." "The GDP figures provide a clear indication that the economy is, so far,   tracking what he has described as the 'narrow pathway' to a 'soft landing'. " "Today's figures showed clear evidence that monetary policy is working." But Mr Bloxham sees one more interest rate rise by the RBA of 0.25 per cent before the end of the year. "The risk remains that the RBA may yet have to lift its cash rate a bit further to ensure that inflation gets back to its target band over what it deems to be a 'reasonable timeframe'."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HSBC sees one more rate rise despite slowing economy

children.content: As we've been focusing on today, the economy is being weighed down by higher interest rates after 12 increases since May last year.
Consumer spending was anaemic over the June quarter, and Australia saw the largest fall in the terms of trade, the difference between export and import prices, since June 2009.
The ABS says a warmer northern hemisphere winter reduced demand for coal and liquefied natural gas.
Also iron ore prices fell because of weaker demand from China's construction and manufacturing industries.
While prices fell, exports rose, driven by more international students coming here for education and increased tourism.
HSBC chief economist Paul Bloxham says the Reserve Bank's interest rate rises are working to cool the economy.
"Today's GDP figures are likely to have been welcomed by the RBA   and, in particular, by Governor Lowe, whose seven-year term is about to end."
"The GDP figures provide a clear indication that the economy is, so far,   tracking what he has described as the 'narrow pathway' to a 'soft landing'. "
"Today's figures showed clear evidence that monetary policy is working."
But Mr Bloxham sees one more interest rate rise by the RBA of 0.25 per cent before the end of the year.
"The risk remains that the RBA may yet have to lift its cash rate a bit further to ensure that inflation gets back to its target band over what it deems to be a 'reasonable timeframe'."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Senate has passed a law to allow competition in the transfer of stock ownership. The market operator, the Australian Securities Exchange carries out most clearing and settlement services in Australia. But a failed software overhaul of its trading system saw the federal government open up the market to other players. Here's Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones: "The legislation which passed through the Senate today will support competition in clearing and settlement services, which are critical to the functioning and stability of financial markets." "It creates a framework for fair, transparent and non‑discriminatory access to market infrastructure for any emerging competitors, allowing them to offer their own clearing and settlement services." The new rules also give the Reserve Bank and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission greater oversight of clearing and settlement providers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have the power to arbitrate disputes between parties around the price and access to clearing and settlement services.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to face competition in share settlement and clearing

children.content: The Senate has passed a law to allow competition in the transfer of stock ownership.
The market operator, the Australian Securities Exchange carries out most
clearing and settlement services
in Australia.
But a failed software overhaul of its trading system saw the federal government open up the market to other players.
Here's Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones:
"The legislation which passed through the Senate today will support competition in clearing and settlement services, which are critical to the functioning and stability of financial markets."
"It creates a framework for fair, transparent and non‑discriminatory access to market infrastructure for any emerging competitors, allowing them to offer their own clearing and settlement services."
The new rules also give the Reserve Bank and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission greater oversight of clearing and settlement providers.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have the power to arbitrate disputes between parties around the price and access to clearing and settlement services.

items.synopsis: Ernie Bot, a generative AI chatbot, is now fully accessible to the public. But how powerful can it be in a realm of heavily censored internet use, and how does this fit into China's vision of becoming the world leader in AI?

title.children: 'Layers of censorship': Ernie Bot is China's answer to ChatGPT – is it AI's 'great leap forward'?
